column1: Describe The Contempt of Courts Act, 1971
column2: This act defines and limits the power of courts in punishing acts that disrespect or disobey judicial authority, preserving the court's integrity.

column1: Describe The Court Fees Act, 1870
column2: This act governs the fees required for filing various types of legal documents in Indian courts, aiming to regulate and standardize court-related charges.

column1: Describe The Judges (Protection) Act, 1985
column2: This act provides legal protection to judges, ensuring they cannot be held liable in civil or criminal proceedings for official actions performed in good faith.

column1: Describe The Judges Inquiry Act, 1968
column2: This act establishes procedures for investigating misconduct or incapacity allegations against high-ranking judicial officers in India, including Supreme Court and High Court judges.

column1: Describe The Supreme Court (Number Of Judges) Amendment Act, 2019
column2: This amendment modifies the strength of Supreme Court judges to accommodate the increasing case backlog, enhancing judicial capacity.

column1: Describe The Delhi High Court Act, 1966
column2: This act establishes the Delhi High Court and sets its jurisdiction, administrative powers, and procedural regulations.

column1: Describe Judges Inquiry Rule, 1969
column2: This rule provides detailed procedures for investigating complaints against judges under the Judges Inquiry Act, 1968.

column1: Describe The Gram Nyayalayas Act, 2008
column2: This act establishes local courts, known as Gram Nyayalayas, to provide speedy and accessible justice in rural areas, handling minor civil and criminal cases.

column1: Describe The Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987
column2: This act aims to provide free and competent legal services to weaker sections of society, promoting equal access to justice.

column1: Describe the Constitution of India
column2: The Constitution of India is the supreme law of India, laying the foundation for the country's legal, political, and administrative framework.

column1: Describe The Supreme Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Act, 1958
column2: This act sets forth the salaries, allowances, and other service conditions for Supreme Court judges in India, defining the benefits entitled to them during their tenure.

column1: Describe The High Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Act, 1954
column2: This act establishes the pay structure, allowances, and service conditions for High Court judges across India, covering aspects of their tenure and retirement.

column1: Describe the Amendment in High Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Act, 1954 and Supreme Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions) Act
column2: This amendment updates the provisions related to the salaries, pensions, and service benefits of both High Court and Supreme Court judges, ensuring fair compensation in line with changing economic conditions.

column1: Describe The Family Courts Act, 1984
column2: This act provides for the establishment of Family Courts to promote conciliation and secure speedy settlements in family disputes, including matters like divorce, child custody, and support.

column1: Describe The Family Courts Amendment Act, 1991
column2: This amendment refines provisions within the Family Courts Act, 1984, further enabling efficient handling of family-related cases and improving the judicial process in family courts.

column1: Describe The Supreme Court Judges (Travelling Allowance) Rules, 1959
column2: These rules specify the travel allowances and entitlements for Supreme Court judges, covering official travel expenses and related allowances.

column1: Describe The Supreme Court Judges Rules, 1959 (as on 21.09.2022)
column2: These rules lay out detailed administrative guidelines for the service conditions of Supreme Court judges, updated as of September 2022, encompassing roles, entitlements, and procedural standards.

column1: Describe The High Court Judges Travelling Allowance Rules, 1956
column2: These rules govern the travel allowances for High Court judges, detailing compensations for official travel to ensure consistent travel benefits.

column1: Describe The High Court Judges Rules, 1956 (As on 21.09.2022)
column2: These rules outline comprehensive service regulations for High Court judges, last updated on September 2022, encompassing their duties, entitlements, and conditions of service.

column1: Who appoints the Chief Justice of India and Supreme Court Judges?
column2: The President appoints the Chief Justice of India and the Judges of the Supreme Court under clause (2) of Article 124 of the Constitution.

column1: How is the Chief Justice of India appointed?
column2: The Chief Justice of India is appointed from the seniormost Judge of the Supreme Court considered fit for the office. The Union Minister of Law will seek the recommendation of the outgoing Chief Justice for the next appointment.

column1: What happens if there is doubt about the seniormost Judge's fitness?
column2: If there is any doubt about the fitness of the seniormost Judge to hold the office, consultation with other Judges as envisaged in Article 124 (2) of the Constitution will be made.

column1: What is the process for appointing Judges of the Supreme Court?
column2: When a vacancy is expected, the Chief Justice of India initiates a proposal and forwards a recommendation to the Union Minister of Law, Justice, and Company Affairs, formed in consultation with a collegium of the four seniormost puisne Judges of the Supreme Court.

column1: How is the opinion of the collegium formed?
column2: The opinion of the collegium regarding recommendations, as well as the seniormost Judge from the candidate's High Court, must be made in writing and transmitted to the Government of India as part of the record.

column1: What happens after the final recommendation of the Chief Justice?
column2: The Union Minister of Law will present the recommendations to the Prime Minister, who will advise the President on the appointment.

column1: What certification is required from the selected person?
column2: A certificate of physical fitness signed by a Civil Surgeon or a District Medical Officer is required from the selected person, regardless of their current service status.

column1: What is the process for appointing an Acting Chief Justice?
column2: The President appoints the Acting Chief Justice under Article 126 of the Constitution. The seniormost available Judge of the Supreme Court will be appointed to perform the duties if there is a vacancy. The appointment will be announced and notified in the Gazette of India.

column1: How are Ad hoc Judges appointed to the Supreme Court?
column2: The Chief Justice of India requests a qualified High Court Judge to attend the Supreme Court with the President's consent. This requires the Chief Justice of the concerned High Court's approval, after which the Union Minister of Law will put up the recommendation to the Prime Minister.

column1: What is the process for retired Judges attending Supreme Court sittings?
column2: Under Article 128, the Chief Justice of India can request a retired Supreme Court Judge to act as a Judge of the Supreme Court with the President's consent. The Chief Justice will sound the retired Judge about their willingness and then communicate the name and period required to the Union Minister of Law.

column1: Appointment of Chief Justice
column2: The Government, in consultation with the Chief Justice of India, decides to appoint Chief Justices from outside. For initial appointments, Article 217 must be followed, and for Jammu & Kashmir, section 95 of its Constitution applies. Transfers of Chief Justices are governed by Article 222, with additional provisions for Jammu & Kashmir. Seniority for elevation to Chief Justice is based on their seniority in their own High Courts. A puisne Judge close to retirement may be considered for Chief Justice if a vacancy arises within a year.

column1: Initiation of Proposal
column2: The proposal for the appointment of a Chief Justice is initiated by the Chief Justice of India, ensuring timely completion at least one month before the anticipated vacancy. Recommendations are made in consultation with the two senior-most Supreme Court Judges. Views of the senior-most colleague familiar with the concerned High Court are also sought.

column1: Process for Appointment
column2: Recommendations from the Chief Justice of India are sent to the Union Minister of Law, who then obtains views from the State Government. Following this, the Minister submits proposals to the Prime Minister, who advises the President. The appointment is announced by the Department of Justice once approved.

column1: Appointment of Acting Chief Justice
column2: Appointments of Acting Chief Justices are made by the President under Article 223. The Chief Justice must notify all concerned about any leave or inability to perform duties in advance. The seniormost puisne Judge is appointed as Acting Chief Justice, and if a different Judge is proposed, the regular Chief Justice appointment procedure must be followed.

column1: Appointment of Permanent Judges
column2: Permanent Judges are appointed by the President under Article 217. The Chief Justice must communicate recommendations to the Chief Minister at least 6 months prior to expected vacancies, after consulting two seniormost colleagues. Recommendations should include detailed statistics on the Judge's performance. The Chief Justice initiates the proposal, and if the Chief Minister recommends a name, it should be forwarded to the Chief Justice for consideration.

column1: Procedure for Recommendations
column2: The Governor forwards recommendations from the Chief Minister to the Union Minister of Law. The Minister considers the recommendations and submits them to the Chief Justice of India for advice, who consults with the two senior-most Supreme Court Judges. The final recommendations are sent to the Union Minister, who submits them to the Prime Minister for Presidential approval.

column1: Appointments in Multi-State Jurisdiction
column2: For High Courts with jurisdiction over multiple states, the Chief Justice initiates the proposal, and the Governor coordinates obtaining views from other Governors and Chief Ministers. Any differing recommendations from State authorities must be sent back to the Chief Justice for consideration.

column1: Appointment of Additional Judges
column2: Additional Judges are appointed by the President under Article 224. The State Government must obtain Central Government sanction for additional posts. The appointment procedure is similar to that for permanent Judges, except that a medical certificate is not required. The Chief Justice must not recommend an Additional Judge when a permanent Judge vacancy exists.

column1: Appointment of Acting Judges
column2: Acting Judges can be appointed by the President under Article 224(2) for periods of at least three months. The same procedure as for permanent Judges applies, but no medical certificate is necessary. Recommendations should avoid suggesting current Bar members.

column1: Attendance of Retired Judges at High Court
column2: Under Article 224A, the Chief Justice may request a retired Judge to act as a Judge with the President's consent. The Chief Justice must obtain the retired Judge's consent and communicate the name and duration of service to the Chief Minister, who will forward the recommendation to the Union Minister of Law.

column1: Who appoints the Chief Justice of India?
column2: The Chief Justice of India and the Judges of the Supreme Court are appointed by the President under clause (2) of Article 124 of the Constitution.

column1: How is the Chief Justice of India appointed?
column2: Appointment to the office of the Chief Justice of India should be of the seniormost Judge of the Supreme Court considered fit to hold the office.

column1: What is the role of the outgoing Chief Justice?
column2: The Union Minister of Law, Justice and Company Affairs would seek the recommendation of the outgoing Chief Justice of India for the appointment of the next Chief Justice of India.

column1: What happens if there is doubt about a Judge's fitness?
column2: Consultation with other Judges as envisaged in Article 124 (2) of the Constitution would be made for the appointment of the next Chief Justice of India.

column1: What is the process after the Chief Justice's recommendation?
column2: After receipt of the recommendation, the Union Minister of Law, Justice and Company Affairs will put up the recommendation to the Prime Minister, who will advise the President in the matter of appointment.

column1: How is a Judge of the Supreme Court appointed?
column2: The Chief Justice of India will initiate a proposal and forward his recommendation to the Union Minister of Law, Justice and Company Affairs to fill up the vacancy when a vacancy is expected to arise in the office of a Judge.

column1: Who forms the opinion for a Supreme Court Judge?
column2: The opinion of the Chief Justice of India should be formed in consultation with a collegium of the four seniormost puisne Judges of the Supreme Court.

column1: What if the successor Chief Justice is not in the collegium?
column2: If the successor Chief Justice of India is not one of the four seniormost puisne Judges, he would be made part of the collegium.

column1: How does the Chief Justice ascertain views from other judges?
column2: The Chief Justice would ascertain the views of the seniormost Judge in the Supreme Court from the High Court from where the person recommended comes.

column1: What documentation is needed for a Judge's appointment?
column2: The opinion of members of the collegium regarding each recommendation, along with the opinion of the seniormost Judge in the Supreme Court from the respective High Court, must be transmitted to the Government of India.

column1: What is required after the final recommendation?
column2: After receipt of the final recommendation, the Union Minister of Law, Justice and Company Affairs will put up the recommendations to the Prime Minister, who will advise the President in the matter of appointment.

column1: What medical certificate is needed for appointed judges?
column2: The Secretary to the Government of India in the Department of Justice will obtain a certificate of physical fitness from a Civil Surgeon or a District Medical Officer from the selected person.

column1: What happens once the President signs the warrant of appointment?
column2: The Secretary to the Government of India in the Department of Justice will announce the appointment and issue the necessary notification in the Gazette of India.

column1: How is an acting Chief Justice appointed?
column2: Appointment of acting Chief Justice is to be made by the President under Article 126 of the Constitution, with the seniormost available Judge of the Supreme Court being appointed to perform the duties of the office.

column1: What is the process for appointing ad hoc judges?
column2: The Chief Justice of India may request a qualified High Court Judge to attend the Supreme Court sittings if there is not a quorum of Judges available, with consent from the President and after consultation with the concerned High Court.

column1: How are retired judges involved in Supreme Court sittings?
column2: The Chief Justice of India may request any person who has held the office of a Judge of the Supreme Court to sit and act as a Judge of the Supreme Court, with prior consent from the President.

column1: What was the Government's observation regarding the enhancement of pecuniary jurisdiction?
column2: The Government observed that increasing the pecuniary jurisdiction would lessen the burden on the High Court and improve the disposal of cases in subordinate courts. Additionally, it would facilitate public access to District Courts within their vicinity, providing "Justice at Doorstep."

column1: What was introduced in Parliament regarding the pecuniary limits of the District Courts?
column2: A proposal was received from the Government of NCT of Delhi seeking amendments in the Delhi High Court Act, 1966, to enhance the pecuniary limits of the District Courts of Delhi. This resulted in the introduction of The Delhi High Court (Amendment) Bill, 2015, in Parliament.

column1: What was the outcome of The Delhi High Court (Amendment) Bill, 2015?
column2: The Bill was considered and passed by both Houses of Parliament. It received the assent of the President of India on 10.08.2015 and was brought into force effective from 26.10.2015.

column1: How does increasing the pecuniary jurisdiction benefit the public?
column2: Increasing the pecuniary jurisdiction of District Courts would lessen the burden of the Delhi High Court, improve case disposal in subordinate courts, and facilitate access to the general public to 11 District Courts located in 6 District Court Complexes, ensuring speedy justice at their doorstep.

column1: What does Article 348(1) of the Constitution of India state regarding court proceedings?
column2: Article 348(1) provides that all proceedings in the Supreme Court and in every High Court shall be in English language until Parliament by law otherwise provides.

column1: What does Article 348(2) allow concerning the use of regional languages in High Court proceedings?
column2: Article 348(2) allows the Governor of a State, with the President's consent, to authorize the use of Hindi or any other language for official purposes in the proceedings of the High Court, provided that decrees, judgments, or orders passed by such High Courts are in English.

column1: What does the Official Language Act, 1963 state regarding language use in High Court judgments?
column2: The Official Language Act, 1963 reiterates that the use of Hindi or a State's official language, in addition to English, may be authorized by the Governor of the State for judgments, decrees, etc., made by the High Court for that State, with the President's consent. No law has been made by Parliament so far.

column1: What recommendation did the 18th Law Commission of India make regarding the use of Hindi in the Supreme Court?
column2: The 18th Law Commission, in its 216th Report (2008), recommended that the higher judiciary should not be subjected to any change regarding language use in the current societal context, a stance accepted by the Government.

column1: Which states have authorized the use of Hindi in High Court proceedings?
column2: Hindi has been authorized in the proceedings and judgments of the High Courts in Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, and Bihar.

column1: What proposals have been received from other states regarding language use in High Court proceedings?
column2: Proposals have been received from Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, Chhattisgarh, West Bengal, and Karnataka to permit the use of Tamil, Gujarati, Hindi, Bengali, and Kannada in the proceedings of their respective High Courts.

column1: What was the outcome of proposals for using regional languages in High Courts?
column2: The Chief Justice of India, after deliberations, decided not to accept the proposals for using regional languages in High Courts. This decision was reiterated in response to subsequent requests from the Government of Tamil Nadu for reconsideration.

How does the Department of Justice (DoJ) receive public grievances?
column2: The DoJ receives a large number of grievances through the President?? Secretariat, Vice-President?? Secretariat, PMO, and directly from citizens via the online CPGRAMS Portal. It is rated as one of the 20 largest grievance-receiving Departments by the Department of Administrative Reforms & Public Grievances.

column1: What types of grievances does the Department of Justice handle?
column2: The DoJ is mandated to deal with grievances related to the appointment of Judges of the Supreme Court/High Courts, legal assistance, legal aid, legal awareness, e-Courts, and Judicial Reforms.

column1: What happens to grievances related to the judiciary?
column2: Grievances related to the judiciary are forwarded electronically to the Secretary General of the Supreme Court of India or the Registrar General of the concerned High Court for further action, and a copy is sent to the grievance holder for information.

column1: How are grievances examined within the Department of Justice?
column2: Grievances received are considered and examined by the Judiciary as per their internal mechanisms and procedures. The DoJ cannot inform the grievance holders of the outcome in such cases.

column1: What is the purpose of the CPGRAMS Version 7.0 launched in the DOJ?
column2: CPGRAMS Version 7.0 aims to reduce the travel time for resolving grievances, allowing citizens to directly reach the concerned officer responsible for resolution by selecting from a dropdown menu.

column1: How many grievances were received and disposed of in September 2024?
column2: In September 2024, the DoJ received 1,086 grievances through CPGRAMS, of which 801 were disposed of, leaving a cumulative pendency of 285 grievances.

column1: What is the role of the Judiciary according to the Constitution of India?
column2: The Judiciary is an independent organ of the State under the Constitution of India, and the Government of India does not interfere in its functioning.

column1: Who has administrative control over the subordinate judiciary?
column2: The administrative and disciplinary control over the members of the subordinate judiciary in the States vests with the concerned High Court and the respective State Government, which frames Rules and Regulations in consultation with the High Courts.

column1: Does the Central Government maintain records related to court proceedings?
column2: No, the Central Government neither maintains records related to any court proceedings, decisions, or judgments, nor does it have a mechanism to monitor the action taken on them.

column1: Can the Government expedite court proceedings?
column2: No, the Government cannot ask a Court of Law to expedite the proceedings of any particular case, and no action can be taken regarding grievances related to delays in the disposal of cases.

column1: How can a judicial order be challenged?
column2: A judicial order can be challenged only before the appropriate Court of Law as per the prescribed legal procedure, making it futile to file a grievance against a judicial order or judgment.

column1: How are grievances against a Judge handled?
column2: Grievances against a Judge can be taken up for inquiry by the concerned High Court or Supreme Court as per their in-house procedure, and the Government has no role in the disposal of such grievances.

column1: Where can detailed guidelines on grievances be found?
column2: Detailed guidelines on grievances received in the Department of Justice are available on the Department's website at doj.gov.in. Grievances against Judicial Officers must be sent on sworn affidavit with verifiable facts to the Registrar General of the concerned High Court.

column1: What should not be included with grievances filed in court?
column2: Petitions, applications, and other documents to be filed before a Court of Law should not be forwarded with grievances, as these must be presented in person or by a duly authorized agent or advocate on record.

column1: What is the procedure for follow-up on grievances?
column2: As the Judiciary is independent and the Government does not interfere, no further follow-up or correspondence is made by the Government after forwarding a grievance to the concerned High Court or Supreme Court.

column1: How can citizens lodge grievances online?
column2: Citizens can lodge their grievances online through pgportal.gov.in. As a result, no action is taken on grievances received through e-mail.

column1: What should be done once a final reply is given on a grievance?
column2: Once a final reply is given on a grievance, it should not be repeated again.

column1: What was the purpose of the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2018?
column2: The Act aimed to champion the cause of safety and security for women and girls by providing stringent punishments, including the death penalty for perpetrators of rape.

column1: Why were Fast Track Special Courts (FTSCs) established?
column2: FTSCs were established to address the incidents of sexual offences and prolonged trials, providing immediate relief to victims by ensuring expeditious trials for sexual offences.

column1: When did the Department of Justice start implementing FTSCs?
column2: The implementation of FTSCs began in October 2019 as part of a Centrally Sponsored Scheme to set up dedicated courts for the expeditious trial of sexual offences, including exclusive POCSO Courts.

column1: How many States and Union Territories (UTs) have joined the FTSC scheme?
column2: Out of 31 eligible States and UTs, 30 have joined the FTSC scheme, with Puducherry making a special request to join, leading to the operationalization of one exclusive POCSO Court in May 2023.

column1: What was the initial budget for the FTSC scheme?
column2: The initial budget for the FTSC scheme was Rs. 767.25 crore, with Rs. 474 crore as the Central Share to be met from the Nirbhaya Fund.

column1: How long was the FTSC scheme initially approved to continue?
column2: The FTSC scheme was initially approved for a period of one year, covering two financial years (2019-20 and 2020-21). It was later extended by the Cabinet for two more years, up to March 2023, with a total budgetary outlay of Rs. 1572.86 crore.

column1: What is the extended duration and budget of the FTSC scheme approved in 2023?
column2: The Union Cabinet extended the FTSC scheme for another three years, from 01.04.2023 to 31.03.2026, with a total financial outlay of Rs. 1952.23 crore, including Rs. 1207.24 crore as Central Share from the Nirbhaya Fund.

column2: "Strengthening the Administration of Justice through Judicial Education, Research, and Policy Development."

column1: What is the legal status and governance structure of NJA?
column2: NJA is an independent society, founded in 1993 under the Societies Registration Act, 1860. The Chief Justice of India chairs the governing bodies.

column1: How is NJA funded?
column2: NJA is fully funded by the Government of India.

column1: What is the management structure of NJA?
column2: The Director of NJA, appointed by the Chief Justice of India, is the Principal Executive Officer. The academic staff includes positions like Additional Director, Professors, Assistant Professors, and Law Associates.

column1: Where is the NJA located, and what facilities are available on its campus?
column2: Located in Bhopal on a scenic hill, the 63-acre NJA campus offers residential facilities, a library, seminar rooms, an auditorium, and recreational amenities like a gym, pool, and tennis courts.

column1: What is the National Judicial Education Strategy (NJES)?
column2: NJES, developed by NJA, aims to enhance judicial education to promote timely justice and strengthen judicial administration.

column1: What are NJA's vision and mission?
column2: NJA's vision is to improve timely justice delivery. Its mission focuses on reducing delays in cases and enhancing justice quality and responsiveness.

column1: What is the pedagogical approach used in NJA programs?
column2: NJA programs emphasize interactive, problem-solving methods like case studies, simulations, and experiential learning instead of traditional lectures.

column1: How does NJA contribute to the development of law?
column2: NJA organizes conferences for High Court Justices to assess the law and suggest developments to meet the country's justice needs.

column1: How does NJA develop its curriculum?
column2: NJA develops its curriculum based on judicial education needs assessments. High Courts collaborate in setting up a coordinated national education calendar.

column1: How are responsibilities allocated between State Judicial Academies (SJAs) and NJA?
column2: SJAs handle induction education, while NJA focuses on advanced judicial education, addressing national priorities and gaps.

column1: What types of programs does NJA conduct?
column2: NJA conducts programs such as judicial workshops, seminars on substantive law, "train the trainer" sessions, and orientation modules for new appointees.

column1: What are National Judicial Workshops?
column2: These workshops focus on reducing case delays and improving justice responsiveness, covering about 2,500 judges annually.

column1: What are the outcomes of judicial workshops?
column2: Workshops enable knowledge sharing, enhance skills, raise awareness, and foster solutions for challenges in justice administration.

column1: What are National Judicial Seminars?
column2: Advanced seminars focus on specialized law and justice topics, reaching around 1,000 judges yearly.

column1: What are Train the Trainer programs?
column2: NJA trains educators from State Judicial Academies to equip them to deliver judicial education at the state level.

column1: What orientation modules does NJA provide for ADJs?
column2: NJA provides orientation modules for newly appointed Additional District Judges (ADJs) at the request of High Courts.

column1: What is the National Mission for Justice Delivery and Legal Reforms?
column2: The National Mission for Justice Delivery and Legal Reforms was established in August 2011 to reduce delays and arrears in the judicial system and enhance accountability through structural changes.

column1: What are the main objectives of the National Mission?
column2: The main objectives are to reduce delays and arrears in the judicial system and to enhance accountability through structural changes that establish performance standards and capacities.

column1: What approach does the National Mission take?
column2: The Mission pursues a coordinated approach focused on phased liquidation of arrears and pendency in judicial administration, which includes better court infrastructure, increased strength of the subordinate judiciary, and policy measures to reduce litigation.

column1: What improvements are being made to court infrastructure?
column2: Improvements include computerization of courts, increasing the strength of the subordinate judiciary, and re-engineering court procedures for quicker case disposal.

column1: What emphasis is placed on human resource development?
column2: There is a strong emphasis on training and development to improve the skills and capacities of judicial personnel.

column1: Who chairs the Advisory Council for the National Mission?
column2: The Advisory Council is chaired by the Minister of Law and Justice.

column1: What is the composition of the Advisory Council?
column2: The Advisory Council has a wide-ranging membership that advises on the goals, objectives, and strategies of the National Mission and its implementation.

column1: What is the Nyaya Vikas scheme?
column2: The Nyaya Vikas scheme is a Centrally Sponsored Scheme (CSS) for the Development of Infrastructure Facilities for Districts and Subordinate Judiciary, implemented since 1993-94.

column1: What does the Nyaya Vikas scheme provide funding for?
column2: The scheme provides central assistance for the construction of court halls and residential units for Judicial Officers/Judges of District and Subordinate Courts.

column1: What new features were added to the scheme beyond 31.03.2021?

column1: What was the purpose of the Doing Business Report by the World Bank?
column2: The Doing Business Report benchmarked business regulations in 191 economies across 10 areas, including Enforcing Contracts, to evaluate the ease of doing business.

column1: What does the Ease of Doing Business (EoDB) index indicate?
column2: The EoDB index ranked economies, with higher rankings (lower numerical values) indicating better regulations and stronger protections of property rights.

column1: What factors were considered in the Enforcing Contracts indicator?
column2: The Enforcing Contracts indicator measured the time and cost for resolving standardized commercial disputes and evaluated the quality of the judicial process.

column1: Which cities in India were included in the World Bank's survey?
column2: Only Delhi and Mumbai were included in the Ease of Doing Business survey by the World Bank.

column1: What is the role of the Department of Justice regarding Enforcing Contracts?
column2: The Department of Justice is the nodal department for the Enforcing Contracts Indicator and is pursuing reforms to create an effective and efficient Contract Enforcement Regime.

column1: What methodology was used for collecting data for the Ease of Doing Business rankings?
column2: Data was collected through the study of civil procedure codes, court regulations, and questionnaires surveyed by local litigation lawyers and judges.

column1: How did India? ranking in the Doing Business Report change from 2015 to 2020?
column2: India improved from 142nd position in 2015 to 63rd position in 2020, a significant increase of 79 positions. In Enforcing Contracts, India rose from 186th to 163rd position.

column1: What framework is the World Bank working on after discontinuing the Doing Business Report?
column2: The World Bank is developing a new framework called Business-Ready to assess the business and investment climate globally.

column1: What is the historical significance of the Ministry of Law and Justice?
column2: The Ministry of Law and Justice is the oldest part of the Government of India, established in 1833 with the Charter Act, which vested legislative power in the Governor General in Council.

column1: How did legislative power evolve in India from 1834 to 1950?
column2: Legislative power was initially held by the Governor General in Council (1834-1920), then by the Indian Legislature under the Government of India Act 1919, followed by the Dominion Legislature (1947-1949). After the Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950, legislative power was vested in Parliament.

column1: What are the three departments within the Ministry of Law and Justice?
column2: The Ministry consists of three departments: the Legislative Department, the Department of Legal Affairs, and the Department of Justice.

column1: What is the main role of the Legislative Department?
column2: The Legislative Department is responsible for drafting principal legislation for the Central Government, publishing and scrutinizing subordinate legislation, and managing election law and electoral reforms.

column1: What type of legislation does the Legislative Department handle?
column2: It handles legislation related to civil procedure, personal law, and other concurrent fields, as well as unrepealed Central Acts that are currently in force in India.

column1: Where can information about India's legislation be found?
column2: Information about unrepealed Central Acts and all-India legislation can be found on the website of the Legislative Department.

column1: What did the Charter Act of 1833 establish in India?
column2: The Charter Act of 1833 provided for the establishment of a Law Commission for the consolidation and codification of Indian laws.

column1: What change did the Charter Act of 1833 make to the Governor General in Council?
column2: The Act added a fourth ordinary Member to the Governor General in Council, who was to be a legal expert responsible for law-making.

column1: Who was appointed as the fourth ordinary Member of the Governor General in Council?
column2: Lord Macaulay was appointed as the fourth ordinary Member, entitled to participate in the meetings for law-making.

column1: Who was appointed as the Chairman of the First Law Commission in 1835?
column2: Lord Macaulay was appointed as Chairman, with Sir James Stephen serving as the Law Member in his place.

column1: What was the function of the Legislative Department before 1869?
column2: Before 1869, the Legislative Department operated as a sub-division of the Home Department, preparing draft Bills for legislation.

column1: When was the Legislative Department constituted as a separate entity?
column2: The Legislative Department was constituted as a distinct department in 1869 to handle legislative duties.

column1: How did the Legislative Department handle proposals for legislation?
column2: Proposals for legislation were initiated by the relevant department, and the Legislative Department would take charge of the Bill afterward.

column1: Who drafted the Bills for the Council of the Viceroy?
column2: The Secretary to the Legislative Department and the Law Member drafted all the Bills placed before the Council of the Viceroy.

column1: What significant acts were enacted due to the Law Commission's work?
column2: Important acts such as the Indian Penal Code and the Indian Succession Act were products of the Law Commission's efforts, with Lord Macaulay and Sir Henry Maine playing key roles.

column1: What was the significance of the Second Report (1866) of the Law Commission?
column2: The Second Report contained a draft Contract Bill that became law after revision by Sir James Stephen in 1872.

column1: What is the vision of the Legislative Department?
column2: To achieve excellence in legislative matters for accomplishing the objectives set out in the Constitution of India and to transform the Legislative Department into a model drafting office of the Union.

column1: What is the mission of the Legislative Department?
column2: Ensuring consistency and uniformity in drafting Government Bills, Ordinances, and Subordinate Legislation with brevity, clarity, and precision, while building capacity for efficient and timely drafting and restructuring the Institute of Legislative Drafting and Research to provide training in legislative drafting in both English and Hindi. The Department also aims to disseminate information on Principal Legislation in real-time for the benefit of the public.

column1: What are the objectives of the Legislative Department?
column2: The objectives include timely disposal of legislative proposals, implementation of Law Commission Reports related to the Legislative Department, improving legislative drafting skills for officers at the Union and State levels, disseminating information on Principal Legislation, enhancing the use of information technology in the Department? functioning, and facilitating the timely conduct of free and fair elections to Parliament and State Legislatures.

column1: What are the functions of the Legislative Department?
column2: The Legislative Department is primarily responsible for drafting principal legislation for the Central Government, including bills for Parliament, ordinances, President's Acts for states under President's rule, and regulations for Union territories. It also oversees election laws and maintains up-to-date statutes enacted by Parliament.

column1: What does the Administration I Section do?
column2: Handles establishment matters for staff and officers in the Legislative Department and the Official Languages Wing, as well as Group ??officers in the Election Commission and staff in Election Departments of Union Territories.

column1: What are the responsibilities of the Administration II Section?
column2: Manages establishment matters for Group ??staff, medical reimbursements, office accommodation, security arrangements, and identity cards.

column1: What functions does the Budget & Accounts and Integrated Finance Section perform?
column2: Prepares budget estimates, coordinates appropriation accounts, audits accounts, and scrutinizes proposals for creating and maintaining posts.

column1: What does the Cash Section handle?
column2: Responsible for salary payments and advances.

column1: What is the role of the Correction Section?
column2: Updates codes and supplements containing acts, ordinances, and regulations for all states and Union territories, and marks and scrutinizes Gazette rules and notifications.

column1: What is the GSRO Section responsible for?
column2: Compiles general statutory rules and orders made under acts in the India Code.

column1: What does the Legislative I Section examine?
column2: Examines legislative proposals for drafting and assesses requirements for Presidential recommendations on certain bills.

column1: What are the duties of the Leg. II & Parliament Section?
column2: Manages elections to Parliament, including general and bye-elections, oversees election law, rules, and handles references from the President regarding disqualifications of MPs and MLAs.

column1: What does the Legislative III Section address?
column2: Addresses matters related to concurrent list entries in the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution, including personal laws and the office of profit.

column1: What is the Printing Section's function?
column2: Edits manuscripts of Central Bills.

column1: What does the Publication Section do?
column2: Publishes revised editions of the India Code, Constitution of India, Manual of Election Law, and more.

column1: What are the functions of the Official Languages Wing?
column2: Prepares and publishes standard legal terminology, translates bills and acts into Hindi, arranges translations into other official languages, and releases grants to promote Hindi and regional languages in law.

column1: What is the role of Vidhi Sahitya Prakashan?
column2: Brings out authoritative Hindi versions of reportable judgments from the Supreme Court and High Courts, publishes legal literature in Hindi, and holds exhibitions to promote legal literature available in Hindi.

column1: What are Gram Nyayalayas?
column2: Gram Nyayalayas are judicial bodies established to provide affordable and quick access to justice for citizens in rural areas, allowing them to access justice at their doorsteps.

column1: When was the Gram Nyayalayas Act passed?
column2: The Gram Nyayalayas Bill was passed by Parliament on December 22, 2008, and the Act came into force on October 2, 2009.

column1: Which states are exempt from the Gram Nyayalayas Act?
column2: The Act extends to the whole of India except for the states of Nagaland, Arunachal Pradesh, Sikkim, and certain tribal areas specified in the Sixth Schedule of the Constitution within Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram.

column1: What are the key features of Gram Nyayalayas?
column2:
Some key features include:
  • Providing inexpensive justice at the doorstep of rural people.
  • Establishment for every intermediate Panchayat or group of contiguous Panchayats.
  • Located at the headquarters of the intermediate Panchayat, with periodic visits to villages.
  • Trying specified criminal and civil cases using a summary procedure.
  • Encouraging conciliation between parties.
  • Guided by principles of natural justice, not strictly bound by the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

column1: What funding support is provided for establishing Gram Nyayalayas?
column2: A scheme of central assistance was formulated to cover initial non-recurring expenses up to ??18.00 lakhs per Gram Nyayalaya and 50% of the recurring expenses for the first three years, capped at ??3.2 lakhs per court annually. This scheme has been extended until March 31, 2026, with a budget of ??50 crores allocated for Gram Nyayalayas.

column1: What is the performance review process for Gram Nyayalayas?
column2: A review of the performance of Gram Nyayalayas will be conducted after one year to assess their efficacy in providing speedy and affordable justice to the rural marginalized.

column2: The jurisdiction can be extended to the entire state.

column1: What is the duration and financial outlay of eCourts Phase III?
column2: eCourts Phase III is a four-year project (2023 onwards) with a financial outlay of Rs. 7210 crore.

column1: What is the main objective of the eCourts Phase III project?
column2: To create a unified technology platform for the judiciary, promoting a seamless and paperless interface between courts, litigants, and stakeholders.

column1: How does eCourts Phase III aim to enhance access to justice?
column2: By digitizing court records, implementing e-Filing/e-Payments, and establishing eSewa Kendras for those without technology access.

column2: Expected outcomes include reduced costs for court proceedings, enhanced accuracy and transparency, improved access to judicial services, and a significant reduction in case pendency.

column1: What is the e-Committee?
column2: The e-Committee, Supreme Court of India, oversees the Information and Communication Technology (ICT) initiatives in the Indian judicial system.

column1: What is the main responsibility of the e-Committee?
column2: The e-Committee is responsible for supervising the e-Courts Project, which is part of the National Policy and Action Plan for ICT implementation in the judiciary.

column1: Who funds and monitors the e-Courts Project?
column2: The e-Courts Project is monitored and funded by the Department of Justice, Ministry of Law and Justice, Government of India.

column1: What is the vision of the e-Courts Project?
column2: The vision is to transform the judicial system of India through ICT enablement of courts.

column1: What are the main objectives of the e-Courts Project?
column2: The objectives include providing efficient citizen-centric services, developing justice delivery systems, automating processes, and enhancing judicial productivity.

column1: How does the e-Courts Project aim to enhance accessibility?
column2: By automating processes to ease information access for stakeholders and ensuring a cost-effective and transparent justice delivery system.

column1: What prompted the formation of the e-Committee?
column2: The overwhelming need for reforming the judicial sector in India through the adoption of new technologies led to the proposal of the e-Committee by the then Chief Justice of India, Mr. Justice R.C. Lahoti.

column1: What was the primary goal of the e-Committee?
column2: The primary goal was to formulate a National Policy enabling the Indian judiciary to prepare for the digital age and enhance the efficiency of the justice delivery system.

column1: What are some key functions of the digital platforms created by the e-Committee?
column2: The digital platforms enable stakeholders to access judicial data in real-time, track case statuses, manage pendency, fast-track case categories, utilize court resources efficiently, and analyze data for monitoring judicial effectiveness.

column1: Who are the stakeholders that benefit from the digital platforms?
column2: Stakeholders include litigants, lawyers, governmental/law enforcement agencies, and ordinary citizens.

column1: How does the e-Committee's initiative aim to improve the judicial system?
column2: By applying technologies and communication tools, the initiative aims to make the justice delivery system more efficient and accessible for various stakeholders.

column2: Virtual Courts aim to eliminate the physical presence of litigants and advocates in court, reducing footfalls and saving judicial time and resources.

column1: How are beneficiaries connected to pro bono advocates?

column1: What services are offered under Nyaya Bandhu?
column2: The services include Pro Bono Panels at High Courts, Pro Bono Club Schemes at Law Schools, and direct connections between beneficiaries and pro bono lawyers via the mobile application.

column1: What is the aim of the Nyaya Bandhu outreach?
column2: The outreach aims to create a database of pro bono advocates, connect these advocates with registered beneficiaries, and advance the pro bono culture in the country.

column1: What initiatives are included in creating an ecosystem for pro bono legal services?

column1: What is the background of the Legal Literacy and Legal Awareness Programme?
column2: The Department of Justice (DoJ) has formulated a scheme named "Designing Innovative Solutions and Holistic Approach Scheme," expanding the Legal Literacy and Legal Awareness Programme to an all-India level. It aims for a multi-stakeholder, progressive approach to empower vulnerable sections with access to their legal rights and entitlements.

column1: What are the key objectives of the programme?
column2: The objectives include: Using technology to expand delivery scope, mainstreaming legal literacy through partnerships, building capacity using existing grassroots workforce, developing indicators for effectiveness measurement, and conducting concurrent evaluations and assessments.

column1: What collaborations are involved in this initiative?
column2: Collaborations include the Ministry of Panchayati Raj, which developed short movies for dissemination, and the Department of School Education & Literacy, which uploaded legal literacy content on the DIKSHA portal. Various National Law Universities are involved in initiatives for digital legal literacy and training sessions.

column1: What specific projects are being implemented under this initiative?
column2: Specific projects include training and sensitization programs on legal literacy across various states, documentation of customary laws in the North Eastern Region, and training programs on women's rights and child sexual abuse.

column1: Who are the partner agencies involved?
column2: Partner agencies include National Law Institute University (NLIU), Madhya Pradesh, National Law School of India University (NLSIU), Karnataka, Law Research Institute (LRI), Assam, and Meghalaya State Legal Services Authority (MSLSA), Shillong.

column1: How is the initiative structured to reach its objectives?
column2: The initiative integrates innovative ideas and tools, focuses on capacity building, and utilizes a grassroots workforce. It emphasizes collaboration with various stakeholders to create a comprehensive framework for promoting legal literacy and awareness nationwide.

column1: What is the background of NALSA?
column2: Article 39A of the Constitution of India mandates free legal aid to the poor and weaker sections, ensuring justice for all. The Legal Services Authorities Act was enacted in 1987, establishing a nationwide network for providing free legal services. NALSA monitors and evaluates the implementation of these programs and lays down policies to ensure access to legal services.

column1: How is NALSA structured?
column2: NALSA comprises State Legal Services Authorities, High Court Legal Services Committees, District Legal Services Authorities, and Taluk Legal Services Committees, which implement policies and provide free legal services and conduct Lok Adalats. A Supreme Court Legal Services Committee administers legal services related to the Supreme Court.

column1: What are the main functions of NALSA?
column2: NALSA is responsible for laying down policies and guidelines for legal services, ensuring the provision of free and competent legal services, organizing Lok Adalats for dispute resolution, and conducting legal awareness camps in rural areas.

column1: What free legal services are provided by NALSA?
column2: Free legal services include payment of court fees, providing legal representation, obtaining certified copies of documents, and preparation of legal documents. Eligible individuals include women, children, SC/ST members, and others with income below a specified limit.

column1: What is a Lok Adalat?
column2: A Lok Adalat is an alternative dispute resolution forum where disputes pending in court or at the pre-litigation stage are settled amicably. Awards made by Lok Adalats are deemed civil court decrees and are final and binding. E-Lok Adalats have also been introduced to enhance access to justice.

column1: What kind of legal awareness programmes does NALSA conduct?
column2: NALSA conducts legal literacy programs, particularly in schools and colleges, and empowers women through routine legal literacy camps. These programs aim to enhance awareness of legal rights and responsibilities among various segments of society.

column1: What are the details of the grant-in-aid released to NALSA?
column2: The National Legal Services Authority receives recurring grants to perform its functions. For FY 2021-22, an amount of ??145 million was disbursed, and the amounts for previous years ranged from ??100 million to ??190 million, intended for various functions under the Legal Services Authorities Act.

column1: What is "Hamara Samvidhan Hamara Samman"?
column2: "Hamara Samvidhan Hamara Samman" is a year-long campaign initiated by the Department of Justice to celebrate India's 75th year as a Republic. The campaign encourages citizens to actively participate in shaping the vision of Viksit Bharat (Developed India) by 2047, emphasizing the importance of legal rights and responsibilities.

column1: What are the main objectives of the campaign?
column2: The campaign aims to empower citizens with knowledge about their legal rights, foster a culture of legal compliance, and reinforce the rule of law to strengthen the nation's fabric. It seeks to unite individuals in a collective effort to build a nation based on progress, inclusivity, and sustainable development.

column1: What activities are involved in the campaign?
column2: Various activities and events will be organized throughout the campaign, both online and offline, to raise awareness about citizens' rights, duties, and entitlements. These activities are guided by three overarching sub-themes: 1. Sabko Nyay ?Har Ghar Nyay: Ensuring justice for all, regardless of socio-economic backgrounds.2. Nav Bharat Nav Sankalp: Committing to a new India driven by innovative 3. Vidhi Jagriti Abhiyaan: Promoting legal literacy and awareness through grassroots initiatives and educational efforts. ideas and renewed commitment.

column1: What is the significance of participating in this campaign?
column2: Participation in "Hamara Samvidhan Hamara Samman" signifies a commitment to collective progress, encouraging individuals to look beyond personal interests and contribute to building a just and equitable nation. It emphasizes the importance of community engagement in promoting legal awareness and ensuring access to justice for all citizens.

column1: How does the campaign contribute to the vision of Viksit Bharat?
column2: By empowering citizens with knowledge of their rights and responsibilities, the campaign fosters a culture of legal compliance and respect for the rule of law. This collective effort aims to create a more just and inclusive society, ultimately contributing to the realization of the vision of Viksit Bharat by 2047, where every citizen can participate in the nation? progress.

column1: What is the Panch Pran Pledge?
column2: The Panch Pran Pledge is a commitment inspired by the Prime Minister of India, focusing on aspirations for a developed India, eradicating servility, pride in traditions, dedication to unity, and instilling a sense of duty in every citizen.

column1: Timeline of the Programme
column2: The programme will run for an entire year, from January 2024 to January 2025.

column1: Who are the Participants?
column2: All citizens of India are invited to participate.

column1: How can citizens participate in the programme?
column2: Citizens can visit the MyGov Platform's activity page to recite the pledge and generate e-certificates. Additionally, Village Level Entrepreneurs (VLEs) in 2.5 Lakh Gram Panchayats will encourage at least 200 citizens visiting the Common Service Centres (CSCs) to read the pledge. The pledge will be available in digital format and posted within CSCs, with QR codes linking to the MyGov campaign page displayed. Brochures and pamphlets will also be distributed.

column1: Expected Outcome of the Panch Pran Pledge
column2: The pledge aims to raise awareness among citizens across 2.5 Lakh Gram Panchayats, fostering patriotism and responsibility. It will be translated into 22 Scheduled Languages through CSCs to ensure broader accessibility and inclusivity.

column1: What is the Nyay Sahayak Programme?
column2: Nyay Sahayaks are community-based messengers generating awareness about legal services offered by the Department of Justice (DoJ) in Aspirational Blocks and Districts. Currently, 460 Nyaya Sahayaks are engaged in this initiative.

column1: Timeline of the Nyay Sahayak Programme
column2: This programme will run for an entire year (January 2024 ?January 2025), with a pilot phase from January 2024 to March 2025.

column1: Who are the Participants of the Nyay Sahayak Programme?
column2: Citizens residing in Aspirational Districts and Blocks identified by NITI Aayog are the target participants.

column1: Methodology of Nyay Sahayak Programme
column2: Nyay Sahayaks will have unique IDs for referral during citizen transactions. Their performance will be linked to incentives. The programme aims to introduce technology with human support at the block level for doorstep delivery of legal services and local participation.

column1: Expected Outcome of Nyay Sahayak Programme
column2: The Nyay Sahayaks will facilitate door-to-door delivery of legal services, assist in case registration, and conduct legal awareness sessions (Vidhi Baithaks) monthly at various locations, targeting cross-sector groups such as School Management Committees and Self-Help Groups.

column1: What is the Nyay Seva Mela?
column2: The Nyay Seva Mela is a state-level workshop cum fair organized across 36 States/UTs, involving participation from DLSA/SLSA/State Law Departments and Legal Aid Clinics of Law Schools. It includes the release of booklets on state schemes, the felicitation of grassroots functionaries, and visits from VIPs/VVIPs.

column1: Timeline of the Nyay Seva Mela
column2: The Mela will take place throughout the year (January 2024 ?January 2025).

column1: Expected Outcome of the Nyay Seva Mela

column1: What are the major sections of the Indian Constitution?
column2: The major sections are: Part I: The Union and its Territory (Articles 1-4), Part II: Citizenship (Articles 5-11), Part III: Fundamental Rights (Articles 12-35), Part IV: Directive Principles of State Policy (Articles 36-51), Part IV-A: Fundamental Duties (Article 51A), Part V: The Union (Articles 52-151), Part VI: The States (Articles 152-237), Part VII: The States in Part B of the First Schedule (Repealed, Article 238), Part VIII: The Union Territories (Articles 239-242), Part IX: The Panchayats (Articles 243-243O), Part IX-A: The Municipalities (Articles 243P-243ZG), Part X: The Scheduled and Tribal Areas (Articles 244-244A), Part XI: Relations between the Union and the States (Articles 245-263), Part XII: Finance, Property, Contracts, and Suits (Articles 264-300A), Part XIII: Trade, Commerce, and Intercourse within the Territory of India (Articles 301-307), Part XIV: Services under the Union and the States (Articles 308-323), Part XIV-A: Tribunals (Articles 323A-323B), Part XV: Elections (Articles 324-329A), Part XVI: Special Provisions relating to certain classes (Articles 330-342), Part XVII: Official Language (Articles 343-351), Part XVIII: Emergency Provisions (Articles 352-360), Part XIX: Miscellaneous (Articles 361-367), Part XX: Amendment of the Constitution (Article 368), Part XXI: Temporary, Transitional, and Special Provisions (Articles 369-371I), Part XXII: Short Title, Commencement, and Repeals (Articles 372-395).

column1: How many schedules are there in the Indian Constitution?

column1: What does Article 14 guarantee?
column2: Article 14 guarantees the Right to Equality, stating that the State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

column1: What rights are provided under Article 19?
column2: Article 19 guarantees the Right to Freedom, which includes the freedom of speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession, subject to reasonable restrictions.

column1: What does Article 21 protect?
column2: Article 21 provides the Right to Life and Personal Liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law.

column1: What are Fundamental Duties as per Article 51A?
column2: Article 51A outlines the Fundamental Duties of every citizen, which include promoting harmony, safeguarding public property, and developing a scientific temper, among others.

column1: What does Article 32 empower citizens to do?
column2: Article 32 grants the Right to Constitutional Remedies, allowing individuals to approach the Supreme Court for the enforcement of their Fundamental Rights.

column1: What is the significance of Article 39?
column2: Article 39 directs the State to ensure equal pay for equal work for both men and women and to protect the health and strength of workers, especially women and children.

column1: What does Article 41 guarantee?
column2: Article 41 provides the Right to Work, Education, and Public Assistance in certain cases, ensuring that the State shall make effective provisions for securing these rights.

column1: What does Article 45 mandate?
column2: Article 45 mandates the State to provide early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the age of six years.

column1: What is the purpose of Article 46?
column2: Article 46 promotes the educational and economic interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other weaker sections, protecting them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.

column1: What rights are provided under Article 300A?
column2: Article 300A guarantees that no person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law, ensuring the right to property as a constitutional right.

column1: What does Article 14 ensure for individuals?
column2: Article 14 ensures that every individual is treated equally before the law and prohibits discrimination based on religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.

column1: What does Article 15 prohibit?
column2: Article 15 prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth and mandates the State to take affirmative action in favor of weaker sections.

column1: What is the significance of Article 16?
column2: Article 16 guarantees equality of opportunity in matters of public employment and prohibits discrimination in government jobs based on religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, or residence.

column1: What does Article 19(1)(a) ensure?
column2: Article 19(1)(a) ensures the Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression, allowing individuals to express their thoughts and opinions freely.

column1: What is the importance of Article 26?
column2: Article 26 grants the right to manage religious affairs, allowing individuals and religious groups to establish and maintain institutions for religious purposes.

column1: What does Article 27 ensure regarding taxes?
column2: Article 27 states that no person shall be compelled to pay any taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion, ensuring the secular character of the State.

column1: What does Article 30 protect?
column2: Article 30 protects the rights of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice, fostering educational development among minority communities.

column1: What is the significance of Article 31?
column2: Article 31 (now repealed) related to the right to property, stating that no person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law, and provided for compensation in case of acquisition.

column1: What does Article 41 guarantee?
column2: Article 41 guarantees the right to work, education, and public assistance in certain cases, ensuring the state provides these rights to citizens.

column1: What does Article 368 deal with?
column2: Article 368 deals with the power of Parliament to amend the Constitution, outlining the procedure for making amendments and ensuring the fundamental framework of the Constitution is upheld.

column1: What does Article 1 state about India?
column2: Article 1 states that India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States, affirming the country? identity as a sovereign nation with a federal structure.

column1: What is the significance of Article 2?
column2: Article 2 empowers Parliament to admit into the Union, or establish new States on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit, facilitating the expansion of the Indian Union.

column1: What does Article 3 enable?
column2: Article 3 enables Parliament to create new States or alter the boundaries of existing States, with the requirement of Presidential recommendation.

column1: What does Article 4 pertain to?
column2: Article 4 deals with the exclusion of certain laws from judicial review regarding the creation of new States or the alteration of State boundaries, ensuring legislative actions are protected.

column1: What does Article 19(1)(g) guarantee?
column2: Article 19(1)(g) guarantees the Right to Practice Any Profession, or to Carry on Any Occupation, Trade or Business, ensuring freedom of choice for individuals in their professional pursuits.

column1: What does Article 21A ensure?
column2: Article 21A ensures the Right to Free and Compulsory Education for children aged six to fourteen years, reinforcing the importance of education in a democratic society.

column1: What is the purpose of Article 22?
column2: Article 22 provides protection against arrest and detention in certain cases, ensuring that individuals have the right to be informed of the grounds of arrest and the right to consult a legal practitioner.

column1: What does Article 23 prohibit?
column2: Article 23 prohibits trafficking in human beings and forced labor, emphasizing the protection of individual dignity and rights.

column1: What does Article 24 state regarding child labor?
column2: Article 24 prohibits the employment of children below the age of fourteen in factories and hazardous employment, ensuring the protection of children? rights.

column1: What rights are outlined in Article 25?
column2: Article 25 guarantees the freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, ensuring religious freedom for all citizens.

column1: What is the significance of Article 26?
column2: Article 26 provides the right to manage religious affairs and maintain institutions for religious purposes, enabling freedom of religion.

column1: What does Article 27 ensure regarding religious taxes?
column2: Article 27 ensures that no person shall be compelled to pay taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion, thus ensuring the secular nature of the state.

column1: What does Article 29 protect?
column2: Article 29 protects the interests of minorities by allowing them to conserve their culture, language, and script, promoting cultural diversity within the nation.

column1: What does Article 30 allow for minority educational institutions?
column2: Article 30 grants minorities the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice, ensuring the right to education for minority communities.

column1: What does Article 32 establish for individuals?
column2: Article 32 establishes the Right to Constitutional Remedies, allowing individuals to approach the Supreme Court directly for the enforcement of their Fundamental Rights, ensuring judicial protection.

column1: What is the role of Article 44?
column2: Article 44 calls for the State to strive to secure for all citizens a Uniform Civil Code throughout the territory of India, promoting equality and justice.

column1: What does Article 46 emphasize?
column2: Article 46 emphasizes the promotion of educational and economic interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other weaker sections, protecting them from social injustice.

column1: What does Article 47 mandate the State to do?
column2: Article 47 mandates the State to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living and to improve public health, emphasizing the importance of health in society.

column1: What does Article 49 address?
column2: Article 49 directs the State to protect monuments and places of national importance, ensuring cultural heritage is preserved for future generations.

column1: What are the articles under Part I: The Union?
column2: Articles 1 to 4: Define the territory of India, admission or establishment of new states, and the powers of Parliament regarding these states.

column1: What are the articles under Part II: The States?
column2: Articles 5 to 11: Relate to the citizenship and rights of citizens in India, including provisions for the acquisition of citizenship.

column1: What are the articles under Part III: Fundamental Rights?
column2: Articles 12 to 35: Guarantee fundamental rights to individuals, including the right to equality, freedom, protection against exploitation, and rights to constitutional remedies.

column1: What are the articles under Part IV: Directive Principles of State Policy?
column2: Articles 36 to 51: Outline the directive principles for the state to promote social and economic welfare, establishing a framework for governance.

column1: What are the articles under Part V: The Union?
column2: Articles 52 to 151: Cover the organization of the executive, the President, the Council of Ministers, and the Parliament of India.

column1: What are the articles under Part VI: The States?
column2: Articles 152 to 237: Deal with the organization of the state government, the Governor, the state legislature, and the relations between the center and the states.

column1: What are the articles under Part VII: The States in the B section?
column2: Articles 238 to 242: This part was repealed by the 7th Amendment in 1956.

column1: What are the articles under Part VIII: The Union Territories?
column2: Articles 239 to 241: Relate to the administration and governance of Union territories.

column1: What are the articles under Part IX: Panchayats?
column2: Articles 243 to 243O: Deal with the establishment of Panchayati Raj institutions in rural areas and the governance framework.

column1: What are the articles under Part IX A: The Municipalities?
column2: Articles 243P to 243ZG: Provide for the governance of urban local bodies and the structure of municipalities.

column1: What are the articles under Part X: The Scheduled and Tribal Areas?
column2: Articles 244 to 244A: Focus on the administration and governance of Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas.

column1: What are the articles under Part XI: Relations between the Union and the States?
column2: Articles 245 to 263: Discuss the distribution of legislative powers and responsibilities between the Union and State governments.

column1: What are the articles under Part XII: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits?
column2: Articles 264 to 300A: Deal with financial matters, property rights, and the state's liability in contract and tort.

column1: What are the articles under Part XIII: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the Territory of India?
column2: Articles 301 to 307: Regulate trade, commerce, and intercourse within India and address restrictions on these rights.

column1: What are the articles under Part XIV: Services under the Union and the States?
column2: Articles 308 to 323: Cover the provisions related to the recruitment and service conditions of government employees.

column1: What are the articles under Part XIV A: Tribunals?
column2: Articles 323A to 323B: Provide for the establishment of administrative and other tribunals for the adjudication of disputes.

column1: What are the articles under Part XV: Elections?
column2: Articles 324 to 329: Discuss the framework for elections in India, including the Election Commission and the conduct of elections.

column1: What are the articles under Part XVI: Special Provisions relating to certain classes?
column2: Articles 330 to 342: Include provisions for the representation of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other backward classes in legislative bodies.

column1: What are the articles under Part XVII: Official Language?
column2: Articles 343 to 351: Provide for the official languages of the Union and the states, and the use of Hindi and other languages.

column1: What are the articles under Part XVIII: Emergency Provisions?
column2: Articles 352 to 360: Discuss the different types of emergencies (national, state, and financial) and the powers of the President during such emergencies.

column1: What are the articles under Part XIX: Miscellaneous?
column2: Articles 361 to 367: Cover various provisions including the protection of the President and the Governor from legal proceedings.

column1: What are the articles under Part XX: Amendment of the Constitution?
column2: Article 368: Specifies the procedure for amending the Constitution.

column1: What are the articles under Part XXI: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions?
column2: Articles 369 to 371J: Deal with special provisions for certain states and Union territories, including the special status of Jammu and Kashmir (historically).

column1: What are the articles under Part XXII: Short title, commencement, and repeals?
column2: Article 372 to 395: Include provisions for the commencement of the Constitution and the repeals of previous laws.
